editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p: TIs a bitter Controver≈øie that our poore ≈øinfull Nation is fallen upon, wherein not onely Armes are ingaged again≈øt Arms, but Bookes written again≈øt Bookes, and Con≈øcience pretended again≈øt Con≈øcience. In this perplexed condition, What ≈øhall the people doe? What ≈øhall they re≈øolve? They expect to receive Councell from Divines, who (though it be a mixt Argument) are mo≈øt likely to ≈øettle them. And they have great rea≈øon to doe it; for the truth is, The world takes ≈øufficient notice that the Cau≈øe, as it now ≈øtands, hath many Divines ≈øtrongly ingaged unto it on either ≈øide, and that their Re≈øolutions have had a great Influence upon it, and upon the people.

That our rejoycing is this, that in ≈øimplicity and godly ≈øincerity, not with fle≈øhly wi≈ødome, but by the grace of God, we have had our conver≈øation to the world, and more abundantly towards our Congregations: To whom wee appeale, and to our Sermons preached among them, whether wee have taught any thing, but humble and holy obedience to all ju≈øt and lawfull authority, ≈øincere love and con≈øtant maintenance of the Truth. body.head: SCRIPTVRE AND REASON PLEADED For Defen≈øive Armes.

div.head: SECT. I. The Question rightly ≈øtated.
div.p: THe Que≈øtion which the Doctor hath propounded, as nece≈ø≈øary to be ≈øcanned is thus expre≈øt [Whether if any King will not di≈øcharge his Tru≈øt, but is bent or ≈øeduced to ≈øubvert Religion, Lawes and Liberties, Subjects may take up Armes and Re≈øi≈øt?] He maintaines the negative, and his principall place of ≈øtrength is, Rom. 13.2. Who≈øoever re≈øists ≈øhall receive to them≈øelves damnation. This he interprets of re≈øi≈øting the higher power, mentioned ver. 1. by which he under≈øtands the King or Supreame; and the re≈øi≈øting, a re≈øi≈øting by Armes. But it ≈øeemes to me, however he make a ≈øhew of di≈øtinct handling his matter, that he either carele≈øly, or ≈øophi≈øtically confounds things, which ought to have been more di≈øtinctly expre≈øt by one that truly de≈øired to have re≈øolved con≈øciences in ≈øo weighty a cau≈øe, as forbearing to defend Religion, Laws and Liberties, when they are all in danger of ≈øubver≈øion. To which purpo≈øe, I ≈øhall make bold to propound divers con≈øiderations towards a better clearing of the true ≈øtate of the que≈øtion; and the ≈øtrength of his proofes for it.

1. It cannot be imagined that a King, who is bent, or ≈øeduced to ≈øubvert Religion, Lawes and Liberties, meanes to doe this by a meere per≈øonall ≈øtrength; (For which no Samp≈øon-like ≈øtrength would ≈øuffice) but by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of others, whether men in office, and tru≈øted with the civill Sword under him, if he can draw them into his de≈øigne, or by the ≈øouldiery ordinary or extraordinary; and that not in one part of the Kingdome, but in ≈øeverall parts, as fa≈øt as he can get in≈øtruments for his turn.

2. Here then will come divers que≈øtions belonging to the ca≈øe. 1. Whether the re≈øi≈øting by Armes, the illegall attempts of an under Officer of Ju≈øtice; ≈øuppo≈øe a Major or Sheriffe, though armed with Commi≈ø≈øion under the Kings hand or ≈øeale, be a re≈øi≈øting of the higher power and damnable. 2. Whether the re≈øi≈øting a Captaine of the Souldiery, comming to act any illegall commands with his bands of armed men, though he al≈øo have a like Commi≈ø≈øion from the King; be a re≈øi≈øting of the King, and ≈øo forbidden? Both the≈øe where the King is not pre≈øent, but in another part of the Kingdome.

3. It will be further que≈øtioned (in ca≈øe he ≈øhould grant re≈øi≈øtance lawfull thus farr) whether it be lawfull to re≈øi≈øt the officers or ≈øouldiers of the King, he being be≈øides them, and animating them with his commands to doe violence? I will ≈øuppo≈øe for the pre≈øent
the Kings per≈øon is and ≈øhall be ≈øafe, notwith≈øtanding the re≈øi≈øtance, or that els the re≈øi≈øtance mu≈øt be forborne. I onely aske, whether his followers commanded by him, ≈øtanding by to doe murthers and rapes may be re≈øi≈øted with armes or not.

4. If he will ≈øay that in all the≈øe ca≈øes re≈øi≈øtance may be made; ≈øo the Kings Per≈øon may be ≈øafe. 1. The King may thanke him for the care of his Per≈øon, but his Power and Authority is as much impugned by this, as by many that plead for the defence now actually under-taken. 2. The Cavaliers and Followers of the King will thanke him never a whit; For they may all be knocked on the head or ≈øtarved, and yet the Kings Per≈øon be ≈øafe. And they would ≈øoon de≈øert the cau≈øe, if this were beleeved, or would be rooted-out, if this were generally practi≈øed; and that is all the Defendants de≈øire, who honour the Kings Per≈øon and authority, as much as the Doctor or any of his fellows, not to ≈øay more; how ever they re≈øi≈øt his Cavaliers.

5. If he will deny re≈øi≈øtance where the King is pre≈øent, becau≈øe there his commands are certainly knowne to be his, which may be doubted of in remote Countries. Then, 1. So ≈øhould it have been expre≈øt for cleare under≈øtanding, and not coucht in uncertainty. 2. Then all the≈øe Cavaliers are ju≈øtly re≈øi≈øted where the King is not pre≈øent, which againe if it were believed and practi≈øed would ≈øoone end the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; For even in the next Pari≈øh to the King, they might be re≈øi≈øted, though not where he appeares and ≈øpeakes. 3. What if it be doubted whether the King be not forced by threatnings and feare of his life to command ≈øo and ≈øo. Kings have been pri≈øoners, and have commanded ≈øo, and by wi≈øe and good Subjects, Ca≈øtles and Townes have bin kept by force of Armes again≈øt ≈øuch as they bad to a≈ø≈øault it, if not yeelded. Our Law ≈øuppo≈øes, The King can doe no wrong, yet ≈øuppo≈øes wrong may be done in his name by his followers; If he then command a notoriou≈øly wicked thing: The Law will ≈øuppo≈øe him forced or the like; And then re≈øi≈øtance ≈øhall be as well lawfull, as if he were ab≈øent. Or even nece≈ø≈øary to re≈øcue him out of ≈øuch wicked hands. 4. What if it be doubted, whether a King be bewitched by ≈øorceries? There have bin ≈øuch things of old, and the Devills power doth not ≈øeeme to be le≈ø≈øned now? 5. What if it be doubted, whether the King be di≈øtracted? A thing that hath befallen Kings as well as meane men? Are ≈øubjects bound from re≈øi≈øting the commands of a bewitched or di≈øtracted Per≈øon to the ruine of Religion, Lawes, and liberties? ≈øtill pre≈øerving his per≈øon ≈øafe. 6. Suppo≈øe it be certaine he is not forced, nor bewitched, nor di≈øtracted: Yet doing as bad as any forced, bewitched or di≈øtracted per≈øon can po≈ø≈øibly doe, by commanding ≈øuch tyrannicall Acts, what rea≈øon can be imagined, why ≈øuch a command ≈øhould tie ≈øubjects hands from re≈øi≈øting his followers, offering to act his tyranny, more then if he were forced, bewitched or di≈øtracted? Is the liberty of his body and mind from tho≈øe violences, an en≈ølaving of his people to his lawle≈ø≈øe lu≈øts of crueltie and mi≈øchiefe?

6. If he ≈øay further, that even his officers or ≈øouldiers, if they have his Seale or warrant may not be re≈øi≈øted in the remote≈øt Country. Then be≈øides the former inconveniences, the≈øe are to be added. 1. Any that come among ignorant common people may abu≈øe them at their plea≈øure, if they will but pretend the Kings Seale or Warrant. It hath bin counterfeited for Briefes: How ordinary would it be, if it might not be re≈øi≈øted? How would malicious men murther with it? Robbers ≈øpoyle with it, and who could remedy it? 2. By this meanes any that had a de≈øigne to depo≈øe the King and u≈øurpe the Kingdome, might by a counterfeit Seale and Warrant, kill all the Kings faithfulle≈øt Subjects, and ≈øtrengthen ≈øo him≈øelfe and his party, as the King ≈øhould after have no power to ≈øave him≈øelfe. Lawes ob≈øerved will ≈øecure ≈øufficiently from this. And
liberty to re≈øi≈øt illegall violences will appeare to be nece≈ø≈øary to the Kings ≈øafety, as well as the Subjects. Kings have ≈øeldome or never bin murthered or depo≈øed, where Lawes have bin pre≈øerved in their vigour: But often where illegall violences have had place. Let this al≈øo not be forgotten.

7. Well but thus the ca≈øe I ≈øuppo≈øe is under≈øtood (if not by the Doctor, yet) by the generall of tho≈øe that take the Kings part again≈øt the Parliament, that neither the King in Per≈øon, nor any of his officers or ≈øouldiers, that have commi≈ø≈øion from him may be re≈øi≈øted, becau≈øe that were to re≈øi≈øt the King, which ≈øay they all, the Apo≈øtle forbids and threatens, Rom. 13.2. But here again I blame the Doctors negligent handling of that place upon divers con≈øiderations further.

1. Without doubt the fir≈øt ver≈øe is to be regarded, as being the foundation of the ≈øecond, as appeares by the word [Therefore] Yet that he hath greatly neglected. Perhaps for feare the ≈øcanning of it would doe him an ill turne, as I ≈øhall by and by endeavour to ≈øhew, by comparing the ≈øubjection commanded with the re≈øi≈øtance forbidden.

2. In the fir≈øt ver≈øe he doth very ill to reade alwayes (except once by chance, as I thinke) higher power for higher powers, and ≈øo never to tell us whether the other powers (who are higher in relation to the common-people, though inferiour in relation to the ≈øupreme) S. Peters governours may be re≈øi≈øted or not? even with Arms. Perhaps this fraudulently al≈øo.

3. In the ≈øecond ver≈øe, he is very carele≈ø≈øe to tell us, whether re≈øi≈øtance (which is three times in Engli≈øh, but there are two Greeke words, the fir≈øt being different from the ≈øecond and third) ≈øignifie all kind of oppo≈øition, though without Armes, to the higher and ≈øupreme power at lea≈øt, but then much more with Arms? Or whether it only ≈øignifie re≈øi≈øting with Armes, and no other there forbidden, and made damnable. Yet this a needfull Que≈øtion, for a con≈øcience to be re≈øolved in, and more ordinarily then about re≈øi≈øting. And ≈øo would well have become the Doctors learning and pretended care of Con≈øcience, and even regard of Authority to have di≈øcour≈øed upon. But ≈øince he hath not vouch≈øafed to doe any of the≈øe, I ≈øhall take the paines to doe it for him, and for the con≈øcientious Readers, as well as I can.

1. The fir≈øt ver≈øe begins, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Let every ≈øoule be ≈øubject to the higher Powers. Here are two que≈øtions. 1. What is meant by being ≈øubject. 2. What by higher Powers. By being ≈øubject is meant yeelding obedience, either active or at lea≈øt pa≈ø≈øive, that is doing or forbearing acccording to command, or ≈øubmitting to ≈øuffering when one do's otherwi≈øe. It cannot be denied but both the≈øe are parts of ≈øubjection, and that ≈øo much is commanded by the word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ at lea≈øt in ≈øome ca≈øes. But the ≈øecond Que≈øtion, What is ment by higher Powers, will cleare in what ca≈øes either of the≈øe is required? By the higher powers then is meant all civill legall Authority, which in St. Peters phra≈øe is of the King as Supreame, or governour (for the≈øe are higher then the people, though lower then the King) but it is to be ob≈øerved that the word is in the ab≈øtract powers, which notes the authority, wherwith the per≈øon in authority is legally inve≈øted, and not the per≈øon in the concrete, lea≈øt that might be under≈øtood of his per≈øonall commands without or beyond, or even again≈øt his Authority. Which conceit the Apo≈øtle doth greatly prevent by u≈øing the word Power, which he doth al≈øo all the while he treats of this matter, except only that once he names Rulers, v. 3.

2. It is to be ob≈øerved that the things about which the authority, and ≈øo the ≈øubjection
in this place is conver≈øant are civill matters, belonging to the ≈øecond Table between man and man. Not that I deny Magi≈øtrates to have Authority to command things belonging to the fir≈øt Table, and that ≈øubjection is due to them in ≈øuch commands concerning Religion, ≈øo that it be according to the will of God. But I ≈øay, that this is to be fetcht from other Texts rather then this. My rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the Roman Magi≈øtrates, of whom properly the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeakes, were ≈øo farre now from commanding things for Religion, that they commanded things again≈øt Religion, and the fir≈øt Table‚ñ™ and therfore certainly the active ≈øubjection at lea≈øt here required is limited to civill matters.

3. And now that ≈øo much as I have ≈øaid is required, active Obedience to legall, civill Authority to all Magi≈øtrates in their legall commands in civill matters; or at lea≈øt pa≈ø≈øive yeelding to the penalty of the Laws, in ca≈øe of not obeying actively; and neither further then to legall commands of legall Authority, appeares by the Apo≈øtles rea≈øon in this 1. ver≈øe. For there is no power but of God; which he redoubles in a ≈øecond phra≈øe, The powers that be are ordained of God, or under God
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Every ≈øoule mu≈øt be under their order, which is „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , becau≈øe they all are ordered by God under him, his deputies and vicegerents in their order and degree, higher and highe≈øt. This is true of all powers, and therefore to all mu≈øt ≈øubjection be performed. And to none hath God ordered or ordained any Authority but legall. Which as none will deny (no not the Doctor him≈øelfe) of other Governours be≈øides the ≈øupreme: So can none with rea≈øon affirme, that any hath more authority then the Laws, whether ≈øpeciall or generall, written or unwritten, have allotted them. Which Lawes God ratifies (being not again≈øt his) and ≈øo the Authority according to them. And this our Doctor al≈øo confe≈ø≈øes (in ≈øence) in m ‚Ä¢ re places then one of his Booke, for active Obedience, that no more is due, but according to the Lawes of God, and the e≈øtabli≈øht laws of the Land. Only he argues for pa≈ø≈øive obedience beyond this, every where. 1. Becau≈øe he argues again≈øt re≈øi≈øtance even of Tyranny. But in a word to refute this from the Apo≈øtles rea≈øon in the fir≈øt ver≈øe. If I be bound to be ≈øubject to tyranny, (or to ≈øuffer violence of a tyrant) by vertue of the commandement here. div.p: He that hath not all the≈øe in his Eye, (I meane not in this Forme or Phra≈øe, but in ≈øen≈øe, ≈øhal never di≈øcern cleerly, nor di≈øcour≈øe rationally of this ≈øubiect of government, our Dr. though he once occa≈øionally mention the Peoples good, as an End upon which Rulers ought to attend, Yet he ≈øpeakes ≈øo little o ‚Ä¢ it, as it had need be a little more rememembred then it is, and Gods glorie al≈øo which is the chiefe≈øt End of all. But indeede the thought and mention of tho≈øe Ends much, would be too cro≈ø≈øe to his purpo≈øe: and therefore hee is wi≈øe in his Generation (as I may ≈øay, if without offence) to forbeare it. Therefore on the other ≈øide. I mu≈øt make bold to tell him, that though the phy≈øicall end of things may be ≈øilenced or ≈øleighted in a Di≈øcour≈øe or Definition, Ye ‚Ä¢ in mo ‚Ä¢ all things (≈øuch as Governm ‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢ ) the End, at lea≈øt the chief End, is a nece≈ø≈øary ingredient of both, D ‚Ä¢ finition and di≈øcour≈øe, and an E≈ø≈øentiall part of it; if a man will con≈øider it, as he ought practically. Let me therefore adde i ‚Ä¢ to his Definition o ‚Ä¢ De≈øcription of Power or Government, and then it will r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s. It is a ≈øufficiency of authority for Command and Coerci ‚Ä¢ n in the Governing of a People, for Gods glory, and the good of the Society. And all the lawfull Power hath this Effect in part, even H ‚Ä¢ athen, Authority redou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s to Gods Glory as the con≈øervatour o ‚Ä¢ Mankind; and effects al≈øo, the Civill good of the Common-wealth.

Now the Dr. ≈øaith, this power it ≈øelfe (not naming the end) is to be di≈øtingui≈øht from the de≈øigning of the per≈øon to beare that Power, and the qualification of that power; this I grant him, and accepting his grant of the two latter being from men, and after their con≈øent, ratified by Gods permi≈ø≈øive Approbation: I defi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a little to examine, how farre that may be granted him which he earne≈øtly contends for, that the Power it ≈øelfe is from God; and what may be inferred from thence for him or us.

His meaning is, that All Men are (as he ≈øaith) bound to ≈øet up and live under Government. This being the Ordi ‚Ä¢ ance and Appointment of God unto men as they are Rea≈øonable Creatures. If he meane this of Parentall Government, That is ≈øet up to their hands, by God in Nature, as long as the Parents and Children live together; and bind the Children to live with their Parents and under them, till either nece≈ø≈øity drive them away, or their Parents di≈ømi≈ø≈øe them. But ‚Ä¢ f he meane this, of Politicall Government, of a People, of many Families, as it is p ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e he doth (and mu≈øt if he will ≈øpeake ad rem) then I cannot ab≈øolutely grant it him, neither will his text or Rea≈øons prove it.

My Rea≈øons of Denyall are fir≈øt, that all Mankind, who≈øe Parents are dead, and were not by them while they lived, Subjected to a Government are naturally free; & ≈øo not bound to part with that free ≈øome (as even a Monarch doth part with much freedome when he takes the Rule) unl ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe they ≈øee a nece≈ø≈øitie, or at lea≈øt a great advantage, for Gods Honour, and their owne and others Good: which is not alwayes to be found in ≈øetting up a politick Government.

2. Wherein I am confirmed, by the con≈øideration of the three great Patriarkes, Abraham, I≈øaac, and Iacob, who while they lived in Canaan, were not within any government, but onely Dome≈øticall, and neither did rule, nor were ruled by the Inhabitants of Canaan, nor joyned with them in a Common gouernment. Though Abrahams Family was very numerous for a Family, yet it would be hard to call him a Monarch, much le≈ø≈øe I≈øaac; and Iacob le≈ø≈øe, who when he went downe into Aegypt, doth not ≈øeeme to have had any Servants, but onely Sonnes, and his and their Wives and Children.

3. And to this may be added, that by all Authors, it ≈øeemes to be late, before any
≈øetled government, (beyond parentall;) any of diver≈øe Families in continuation, came to be in the World.

4. When the World was more emptie as in Abrahams time, a godly man, as he, having a Competent Family, might ≈øub≈øi≈øt without others, joyning in a government with him; and he could not doe them any remarkable good, or gayne glory to GOD by it, they being Pagans. So that it is not (I ≈øay) ab≈øolutely true, that men are bound univer≈øally, as by an Ordinance from GOD, to ≈øet up, live under government in the Drs. ≈øen≈øe. Marriage is GODS In≈øtitution and Ordinance, and more originally then the Government politicall, and nece≈ø≈øary for encrea≈øe, yet are not all of mankinde bound to marry, but for their owne good and comfort, and ≈øo of others, and advancing Gods Glory in both. So it is with Power, or Government. Politicall, though new when the world is peopled; As there is le≈ø≈øe Nece≈ø≈øity of Marriage, then when the World was thinner, (though ≈øtill a Nece≈ø≈øity to many, even to mo≈øt.) So is there more Nece≈ø≈øitie of being within Government to ≈øecure ones ≈øelfe and others from wrong, and doe one ≈øelfe and others good and glorifie GOD in all. And ≈øo farre I grant it Gods ordinance to all.

But one thing more I mu≈øt remember him, and the readers of. Namely that this Power, will not be proved ab≈øolutely to extend, to the making of any Humane Lawes, but onely to ≈øee to the Ob≈øervation of the Lawes of Nature, and of God by His word and ≈øpeciall Revelation both of the fir≈øt, and ≈øecond Table; and to no other power of coercion, then what the Light of Nature will Argue Nece≈ø≈øarie, for the Ob≈øervation of tho≈øe Lawes of Nature. And that all further power, belongs to the third particular, which he calls the qualification of the Power, & depends upon mans Con≈øent (≈øo it be not again≈øt Gods Law and Word,) which I call the extent of the Power. Which if it be true, it ≈øhall be ≈øeene anon, what Con≈øequence may bee drawne from it to the di≈øadvantage of the Doctours purpo≈øe.

And now let us view the Doctors proofs, that Power it ≈øelfe is an Ordinance of God, binding all Mankind, to ≈øet up and live under government. Rom. 13.1. The Powers are of God, and the Ordinance of God, v. 2.

REPL. The Doctor ≈øeemes to have an excellent faculty, to take ≈øo much only of a Text, as ≈øeemes to ≈øerve his turne, and leave out the re≈øt, which at lea≈øt might ≈øeeme to be again≈øt him: the words v. 1. are, There is no Powers but of GOD, The powers that be, are ordained of God. This may be true, when Powers are, and not that there mu≈øt be powers every where, as in the ≈øimilitude before, there is no Marriage but of GOD, the Marriages that be are ordained of GOD. As for Saint Peters Ordinance of Man, or it is in the Originall, Humane Creation, which is more Emphaticall, granting as the Dr. doth, that the qualification, and Per≈øon is from Mans Creation, I will not urge more from ‚Ä¢ he Text again≈øt him.

2. He urges ver. 4 He is the Mini≈øter of God, this yet proves not a nece≈ø≈øitie in all of ≈øetting up Government. But onely when it is ≈øet up to acknowledge the Governour Gods Vice-gerent. So (as before) the Husband is GODS Vicegerent: Yet a Woman not ab≈øolutely bound to be under a Husband. The truth is, Government and Power is from GOD originally in the≈øe re≈øpects, no further. Fir≈øt he hath laid a generall charge upon Mankinde, to advance his Glory, their owne and others good (whom thus are bound to love as them≈øelves) by all meanes not by him forbidden. Secondly, in the parentall Authours, (or proparentall, if the Parents dye in their Childrens Infancy) he hath ≈øhewed them how much Government may conduce to this. Thirdly he declares by in≈øtinct in Nature, that as Parentall
Authority is deputed by him, ≈øo that he affords a deputation to other Governments when once ≈øet up. Fourthly, ≈øhewing all men (now a dayes and long ≈øince) in fully inhabited places of the world, not only a profit, but even a neces≈øity of being within Government (at lea≈øt for his glory, in the Civill good of ≈øocieties) Upon the≈øe grounds we may ≈øay he ordaines and commands all to be within one Government or other; but not ab≈øolutely, nor without relation to this end.

But thirdly, he alleadges. By me Kings reigne, and I have ≈øaid ye are Gods, and the word of God came to them, Joh. 10. That word, ≈øaith he, is the i≈ø≈øuing out of the Commis≈øion for the ≈øetting up a Government over and among the People.

REPL. But none of all this will amount to his Conclu≈øion; 1. Kings reigne by God, that is they are his Deputies. Men could not give them any Authority over them≈øelves unle≈ø≈øe God owned it and by his in≈øtinct had prompted them to it. Secondly, he ≈øaith, Yee are Gods; but this an owning the de≈øignation of the Per≈øon, as well as the Power. This place either proves more then the Doctor urges it for, or le≈ø≈øe. Thirdly, as for his Dixi, the Doctor mi≈øtakes mo≈øt of all For it relates plainly to his owning the Per≈øons, (whom yet he tels. They ≈øhall are like Men: but the Power dies not) and is rather a granting a particular Patent or Commis≈øion to the Per≈øon cho≈øen or ≈øucceeding, then a Commis≈øion (or Originall Writ) to ≈øet up a Government.

His Rea≈øon is no more Univer≈øally True, then his Texts pertinent. God (he ≈øaith) Governs all Creatures, Rea≈øonable, as well as Unrea≈øonable; the lower world by the Heaven, and the Rea≈øonable Creatures Men, by others too ≈øet up in his ≈øtead, &c.

Repl. But what if the Edge of this Rea≈øon be Turned again≈øt him≈øelfe? For by whom according to the Dr. are Kings and Monarks Govern'd? In an Ari≈øtocracy, each of the Governors is Governed by all the re≈øt of his fellowes, and ≈øo in a Democracy, but in a Monarchy, one Governs all, and hee him≈øelf is Governed by none. Either then al mankind are not bound to be under Government (and then all his Texts and this Rea≈øon are alleadged in vain) or el≈øe Kings and Monarks are al≈øo under ≈øome Government, at lea≈øt of the Repre≈øentative Body of thei people (according to what was before alledged from our Lawyers, Rex non habet Superiorem praeter Legem & Curiam Comitum & Baro ‚Ä¢ um, &c.) Let him take his choice. Nor can hee evade this with ≈øaying the Text Speaks of Monarks, and they are called GODS, and ≈øo none above them But 1. I appeale to all Interpreters, whether the P≈øalmi≈øt intend it not (and ≈øo Chri≈øt after him) of all ≈øorts of Judges, and ≈øo Exod. 22.28. Thou ≈øhalt not Cur≈øe the GODS, nor speake evill of the Ruler of the People. Yet this S. Paul acknowledges extended even to the High Prie≈øt the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Goververnour. 2. Is not the Text at lea≈øt meant, of all the Governours in a Democracy, and in Ari≈øtocracy, that they are call'd GODS, yet each hath the re≈øt above him 3. However ≈øtill his Rea≈øon is voyde, for all Rea≈øonable Creatures are not governed by others in GODS ≈øtead; for by his ≈øaying, Monarks are not; and yet they oft times need to be governed ≈øo far as not to be ≈øuffered to undo all by their Governing or el≈øe this Que≈øtion had never bin in the world, which our hearts bleed to be forced to di≈øpute, concerning the power of re≈øi≈øting Monarks.

If now the Dr. will ≈øay that we afford GOD a poore part in ≈øetting up of power for the governing of Men, he had need ≈øeek better proofe or el≈øe he will hardly per≈øwade any more to a con≈øiderate Reader. But perhaps hee will ≈øay I have yeelded him enough, (and more then others have done) that will be ≈øeene by the u≈øe he can make of his a≈ø≈øertion. But in the meane time, I have 2 or 3 Con≈øiderations to propound, from his Texts and Rea≈øon, and my own grants and a≈ø≈øertions.

1. Each one of his Texts ≈øpeaks of more then the Supreame Powers, Rom. 13.9. Plainly Plurall, more then once, and takes in all Ranks, as hath been proved. Saint Peter names Governours to be ≈øubmitted to for the LORDS ≈øake, a≈øwell as the Supreame and I ≈øhould thinke, Sent by him, is by the LORD rather then by the Supreme, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew by the Rea≈øon by and by; and St. Paul hath ≈øaid the powers that he (even the Governors) are ordained of GOD. And Prov. 8. after the words, By me Kings Raigne, follows, And Princes Decree ju≈øtice, By me Princes Rule, and Nobles even all the Iudges of the Earth. This is plaine, a≈øwell for other Governors as Supreme, being the Ordinance of God. And as for P≈øal. 82. and Ioh. 10. I have ≈øpoken before. I wonder then that the Dr. in a Treati≈øe of Con≈øcience, and having that word ≈øo often in his Di≈øcour≈øe makes no con≈øcience of confining the≈øe places (as in effect he doth continually) meerely to Supreme power; It was for his turne indeed, as will appeare more anon But that will hardly ≈øatisfie a Con≈øcience, let him think on it.

But I mu≈øt not forget his rea≈øon now ≈øerving me once more again≈øt him. God governes all men by others in his ≈øtead; now that is done by ≈øubordinate Governours, as well as ≈øupreame (and ≈øo the inferiour and unrea≈øonable creatures by divers ≈øubordinations) and the ≈øubordinate doe ≈øometimes, even ten more then then the ≈øupreame, let him be never ≈øo good; if they be bad. the government and order will be di≈øturbed and perverted, in a large Dominion, becau≈øe his eye and hand can not be but in one place at once, and all may be and will be naught, if tho≈øe under Governours be naught, whiles he his ab≈øent.

But if they be good, they keepe things for the generall tolerably well, how bad ≈øoever he is. For his badne≈ø≈øe then, (as his goodne≈ø≈øe before) will not reach to all places, and ≈øcarcely (though badne≈ø≈øe in a corrupted world will reach further then goodne≈ø≈øe) much further then where hee is pre≈øent. Kingdomes then are governed under God, by other Powers as well as by the preame‚ñ™ and they no le≈ø≈øe ≈øent by him then the ≈øupreame; I ≈øhall make an inference or two from this afterward.

Secondly‚ñ™ meane time I add my ≈øecond con≈øideration. That in all the forementioned Texts the ≈øpirit of God with the mention of Governours authorized and ordained by him, inculcates their duty to him, and their obligation to Ju≈øtice, &c. and that not onely when hee ≈øpeakes to them, P≈øal. 82. and of them at large, Prov. 8. But even when he ≈øpeakes to inferiours to be ≈øubject to them, and e≈øpecially when he forbids re≈øi≈øtance, Rom. 13. And for this cau≈øe they are all to be prayd for, 1. Tim. 2, 2. That we may lead a quiet and peaceable life, in all godline≈ø≈øe and hone≈øty. Which words, if they may not be taken, as intending why God hath ≈øet any in Authority; yet the thing is undoubtedly true, hee never by way of ordinance gave any Authority for any other End.

Tho≈øe Governours then whether ≈øupreame or other, that under pretence of their Authority from Gods Ordinance, di≈øturb the quiet and peaceable life‚ñ™ which the inferiours ≈øhould lead in all godline≈ø≈øe and hone≈øty (as to bee ≈øure they doe, that are bent or ≈øeduced to ≈øubvert Religion, Lawes and Liberties) are farre from being Gods Ordinance in ≈øo doing; and therfore however their power it ≈øelfe, a ≈øufficiency of Authority for command and coercion in governing the People, be from God; yet their Tyranny is not at all from him‚ñ™ by way of Ordinance or Approbation, and ≈øo they that re≈øi≈øt it even with Armes; Re≈øi≈øt not the Ordinance of God, but re≈øi≈øt the violation of his Ordinance, and ≈øo doe nothing unlawfull, though it be a re≈øi≈øting of the ≈øupreame per≈øon.

Thirdly, let it be remembred that St. Peter in the place fore-mentioned, ≈øpeaking of Governours, ≈øuppo≈øe if meant as the Doctor would‚ñ™ ≈øent by the ≈øupreame, adds (for the puni≈øhment of evill doers, and for the prai≈øe of them that doe well.) If then the ≈øupream ≈øend Governours to erect or practi≈øe a Tyranny (to ≈øubvert Religion, Lawes and Liberties (whether under the name of Iu≈øtices of Oye ‚Ä¢ and Terminer, Sheriffes, Commi≈ø≈øioners of Array, or the like) which is to the Puni≈øhment rather of tho≈øe that doe well, and the prai≈øe of Evill doers; St. Peter ≈øaith not a word, to bid be ≈øubject to them, either actively, or ≈øo much as pas≈øively. Nor any where el≈øe in Scripture, I dare be bold to ≈øay it, doth the Spirit of God bid be ≈øubject to Princes or politick Governours, though tyrannous, or perverters of Religion, and Ju≈øtice. I meane not when it ≈øpeaks of them as ≈øuch.

And till then though they have power from God, which is not to be rejected; yet their Tyranny being not from him, but again≈øt him, may, and the Doctor hath not been able (nor will never be) to prove to the contrary.

div.head: SECT. IV.
div.p: IN this Section the Doctor undertakes to treat of the Forfeiture of the Power‚ñ™ and ≈øo of the Re-a≈ø≈øuming of it by the Parliament or People, for the Kings not di≈øcharging his tru≈øt. And denies this Forfeiture, and this power of Rea≈ø≈øuming that Power. But this (he ≈øaith) they that plead for it offer to prove by two or three things laid together. Fir≈øt, that the power is derived from the People by way of Election. Secondly, that there is a Covenant betweene the King and the People. Thirdly, that it is nece≈ø≈øary for a State have a meanes within it ≈øelfe to pre≈øerve it ≈øelfe. Again≈øt all tho≈øe the Dr. argues and I follow him. Onely remembring him that by Forfeiture is not under≈øtood Forfeiture of all Kingly Authority; nor by Rea≈ø≈øuming (as I ≈øaid before) a taking of the whole power from him to them≈øelves, but onely for the particular Ca≈øe in hazard, and for the pre≈øent neces≈øity.

And now to begin with what he fir≈øt mentions the Derivation of power; I mu≈øt tell him that he forges what he before complained of in others; that they confounded the power it ≈øelfe with the per≈øon and the Qualification‚ñ™ I am ≈øure he doth ≈øo here, if ever man did. Hee before granted the Per≈øon and Qualification from men and then they approved of God; and more then that, no man pleads to be derived nor more to be forfeited, plead not for ≈øo much, nor he Pa ‚Ä¢ liament neither. But only the Qualification for he particular Ca≈øe of danger, and till that danger may be ≈øuffici ‚Ä¢ ntly ≈øecured.

Yet here now at fir≈øt, to oppo≈øe the Forfeiture (but of this particular which is only in que≈øtion now before us) he denies the power to be from the People, and appeales to what he hath cleared, which is onely (by his owne ≈øaying‚ñ™ but not altogether as hath beene ≈øhewed) that the Power it ≈øelfe is from God. But for all that, if no more can be ≈øaid again≈øt the per≈øons forfeiting his reigning Power, and ≈øpecially in the Qualifications of it, even for ever, it may undoubtedly be forfeited and ≈øo re-a≈ø≈øumed all of it: which is more then I ≈øay.

Secondly, but he will prove, that though the People have this Power ab≈øolutely (which him≈øelfe hath more then once granted, of the De≈øignation of the Per≈øon and Qualification) yet could they not have right to take it away.

REPL. The King will have no cau≈øe to thank him for his undertaking, as well becau≈øe he doth it not with any great ≈øtrength; as al≈øo becau≈øe hee hath hereby provoked men to di≈øpute even this Ca≈øe; which no way needed, ≈øince the Parliament never pretended to this Right in generall, but rather di≈øclaimed it.

The King ought ordinarily to be tru≈øted, and a ju≈øt King (a David) is worth 10000. nay 100000. of us his Subjects; but the will and Lu≈øt of ≈øuch a Tyrant as the Qu. ≈øpeakes of, is not to be ≈øatisfied upon one (Ionathan or Naboth) the meane≈øt of tho≈øe thou≈øands; yet it mu≈øt be, if he mu≈øt ≈øtill be tru≈øted when he is bent upon extreame Tyranny.

What the Dr alleadges further of the Oathes of Allegeance and Supremacy and the late Prote≈øtation, prejudices not defen≈øive Re≈øi≈øtance, no more then Scripture and Rea≈øon hath done. The Oathes of Allegeance and Supremacy are onely to the Kings Legall power and Authority, which no man di≈øputes again≈øt. The Prote≈øtation is to defend as far as lawfully I may, according to the duty of my Allegiance, His Maje≈øties Royall Per≈øon, Honour and E≈øtate‚ñ™ and a defen≈øive Re≈øi≈øtance, intends no hurt, but defence and maintenance of him in all the≈øe re≈øpects; and ≈øo was never prote≈øted again≈øt. It is therfore vaine that he addes, [The Kings power cannot be prevalent for the good of his people unle≈ø≈øe it be pre≈øerved to him intire, unle≈ø≈øe he hath a power of denyall and of chiefe Command of Armes.]

Repl. But we Argue not again≈øt a King intending the good of his people; but bent to ≈øubvert all Good, and this indeed hee cannot doe, unle≈ø≈øe their hands be tyed‚ñ™ by ≈øome ≈øuch Po≈øitions as the Dr. would make them believe, that they mu≈øt not deny him his power of denyall of their ≈øafety‚ñ™ when hee him≈øelfe (or others under him) meanes to ≈øubvert all Religion, Laws and Libertie.

And now after all the≈øe di≈øcour≈øes, the Dr. ≈øpends above a Page (in the 1. Edition) to ≈øumme up his ≈øtrength, and boa≈øts of his Victory enough and enough. But how ju≈øtly the Con≈øciences of his Readers and mine mu≈øt and ≈øhall Judge now, and God above all. To whom I very willingly appeale as well as he, or any other; who for mine own part, have even in this di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øhewed I am no Idolizer of the Parliaments, nor carryed away with it (as hee charges) as the Papi≈øts with the name of the Church, nor yet do I thinke Religion may be defended any way. For it may not be with lying nor with doing any thing that God hath undoubtedly forbidden. But he hath forbidden ≈øuch defen≈øive re≈øi≈øtance as I have Argued for, my Con≈øcience finds not, notwith≈øtanding the Drs. bigge words, continually mi≈øapplying the indeed
terrible ≈øentences of the Apo≈øtle, again≈øt unlawfull Re≈øi≈øters of the Lawfull Power.

And ≈øo I have done with the maine of the Drs. Booke, which concernes a Divine. The 2. la≈øt Sections, are matters of fact; wherein it is more ea≈øily to ≈øatisfie a mans owne Con≈øcience, then di≈øcour≈øe of it publiquely: becau≈øe it brings per≈øons much on the Stage: and ≈øome of it cannot but reflect on the King. Of who≈øe honour I am ≈øo tender, that I would not willingly have an unworthy thought of him. Neither will I yeeld to the Dr. or any other living Man, in my zeale to His Royall Per≈øon Honour and E≈øtate according to my prote≈øtation. Yet ≈øomwhat mu≈øt be ≈øaid, and the Drs calling for it, will de≈øerve little thankes, nor yet his pleadings for all the actions done, if they be well examined. To that therefore though unwillingly, I come.

div.head: SECT. V.
div.p: IN this Section he propounds the ≈øum of his ≈øecond and third generall, which are much matters of fact. Yet in this above the major part of Votes, hee again ≈ølides into matter of right and mo≈øt illegally and unju≈øtly argues again≈øt the major part of Votes as again≈øt a prevailing Faction. But if con≈øcience may refu≈øe (or ≈øu≈øpend) to con≈øent to ≈øuch Votes under that pretence, in vaine do all numerous Bodies meet; For this principle of his di≈ø≈øolves, and blowes up not only all Parliaments, but all other meetings, Civill or Eccle≈øia≈øticall. For how ≈øeldome are any matters of great importance, once controverted, & concluded by an unanimous Vote of all as one man? And in remote places, who can be a≈ø≈øured in con≈øcience it was ≈øo, though ≈øaid ≈øo? And what a new doctrine of Politie is this, to make every one, in a great A≈ø≈øembly to have a meere Negative, as this upon the matter doth. The King hath it not, in this ca≈øe, much le≈ø≈øe any other ≈øingle Man. But he will not ≈øay ≈øo, if the Major part ≈øhould Vote any thing that plea≈øes his Doctor≈øhip. If they would Vote the Re-e≈øtabli≈øhment of Bi≈øhops Votes and Authority, this were Good with him no doubt, but if it be again≈øt his Po≈øitions, then it's but the prevailing of a faction. So unju≈øt and partiall are Men that di≈øpute and Argue for their own Intere≈øts, though with pretence of Con≈øcience.

But he fir≈øt repeates what he had told us in his fir≈øt Section, that it is agreed, 1. That this Re≈øi≈øtance mu≈øt be, Omnibus Ordinibus Regni Con≈øentientibus. 2. That it mu≈øt be‚ñ™ Legitima Defen≈øi ‚Ä¢ a meere Defen≈øive Re≈øi≈øtance.

Repl. For the fir≈øt of the≈øe if ≈øome agree to it, yet all do not: I cannot for the Rea≈øons oft in≈øinuated and in≈øerted in what went before; meaning it as he doth here of an Unanimous con≈øent in Parliament, for not onely a legall number Voting, ≈øuffices to any Parliamentary Act, being the Major part pre≈øent. But if no Parliament were called or could meet through the ≈øtrength of a Tyranny already prevailing. Nor the Nobility and Gentry and Commons ≈øo much as ≈øend one to another, t ‚Ä¢ know one anothers mindes, through the ≈øeverall Shires of a Kingdome, yet might any one Shire‚ñ™ or part of a Shire, begin to take up Armes to defend them≈øelves by re≈øi≈øting Outragious Attempts of Tyranny again≈øt their Religion Laws, and Liberties, and that from the Naturall Liberty, that all have to be no further Subject then God hath
commanded, or them≈øelues con≈øented with Gods con≈øent; and this originally belongs (as an in≈øeparable priviledge of a Rea≈øonable Creature,) to each per≈øon ≈øingle, and from thence is derived to Parliamentary and Repre≈øentative Bodies, and ≈øo in Ca≈øe of ≈øuch nece≈øsity, is not bound to waite, their A≈ø≈øembling, or Votes, nor to be concluded by them, if A≈ø≈øembled they ≈øhould Vote the contrary by a Con≈øpiracy with the Tyranny: But each may defend him≈øelfe, and each by the Law of charity may (and ≈øhould) al≈øo defend his Neighbour, but e≈øpecially when the danger is common; as all may without any Votes or Commands, runne together to quench a common fire, ≈øtop a breach made by the Sea, re≈øi≈øt a Forraine Invading Enemy: Without I ≈øay, and even again≈øt any Votes or Commands (if any ≈øhould be) to the contrary. Though ≈øtill I grant, Omnibus Ordinibus Regni Con≈øentientibus, out of Parliament, and much more in Parliament, (or the Major part con≈øenting, and much more, few or none di≈ø≈øenting;) makes the defence more Honourable, more Ea≈øie, more Succe≈ø≈øefull; Onely I cannot yeeld it as ab≈øolutely Nece≈ø≈øary to the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of the defence.

But the Dr. proceeds, and would in≈øinu ‚Ä¢ e, that the re≈øi≈øtance begun (in the point of the Militia) not onely found oppo≈øition, ≈øpecially in the Lords hou≈øe, but al≈øo that the Votes were not free. And that their proceedings are declared again≈øt by a greater number than doe remaine in either Hou≈øe, ≈øuch as have beene ca≈øt out, or have withdrawne them≈øelves in di≈ølike of their proceedings.

Reply. Now we are come to matter of Fact, and here in many things which the Dr. hath in the≈øe two Sections, never any people (that de≈øired to ≈øatisfie their Con≈øciences) had ≈øuch advantage, by all ≈øorts of Declarations, Diurnalls, and Writings, ≈øumming up, and repeating actions, and proceedings, both ≈øince the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the Militia ≈øpecially, and even ≈øufficiently before, that he that will goe by an implicite Faith, as the Drs. phra≈øe is, or beleeve only one ≈øide, is inexcu≈øable if he be mi≈øled. All then that that needs be done, to under≈øtanding and vigilant Con≈øciences is, but to awaken their memories, and ≈øend them to their Almanacks (as the Dr. ≈øpeakes) or their Memorialls, and apply them a little to their hands and hearts. To that then the Dr. ≈øaith, may be replyed, fir≈øt, that there was need of ≈øetling the Militia. When once both Hou≈øes petitioned it, the King him≈øelfe acknowledged it. Yet it was oppo≈øed a while by ≈øome in both Hou≈øes, (but the Petition was not con≈øented to at the fir≈øt by the Hou≈øe of Lords.) No marvell; there were Popi≈øh, and Popi≈øhly affected Lords, who≈øe de≈øigne, at lea≈øt to keep Popery among us ≈øtill, and in ≈øome of them no doubt to advance it, by the ruine of this Parliament,) would have been hindred or ≈øpoiled by the ≈øetling it. No marvell then ≈øuch oppo≈øed it; who al≈øo as was noted before, oppo≈øed the ≈øuccours of Ireland, till all the Kingdome almo≈øt cried out upon them and it, with whom joyned (to their great Honour) at le≈øt the mo≈øt, if not all, the Bi≈øhops pre≈øent u≈øually. Only once (as I remember) for Irelands bu≈øine≈ø≈øe there were two or three Bi≈øhops con≈øenting. But when once tho≈øe were outed, and the Popi≈øh and popi≈øhly affected w ‚Ä¢ thdrawn ‚Ä¢ , (even before ≈øome of them withdrew) all Votes pa≈ø≈øed for the Militia ‚ñ™ as now it is. Let con≈øciences now judge, whether ought to be ≈øtuck to, tho≈øe that were for it, or tho≈øe again≈øt it? Secondly, it is altogether fal≈øe that a greater number of the Hou≈øe of Commons have declared again≈øt the proceedings; then have been there, and voted their continuance. About 6 ‚Ä¢ . (and not many more) have been ca≈øt out for their notorious malignancy, and many of them for Actuall
Warre again≈øt the Parliament. But there was ever the Major part for the Militia, and ≈øo for the con≈øequent proceedings. El≈øe (as I ≈øaid before) why came not the Maior part, to out vote them, and ≈øet all Right? Let Con≈øcience judge.
The next thing the D ‚Ä¢ . would prove, is that the Parliament is not upon the Defen≈øive; and then that they keep within the Defen≈øive.

In the fir≈øt, he puts two que≈øtions who was fi ‚Ä¢ ≈øt in Armes? and what is the cau≈øe of the Armes? In an≈øwering the former, becau≈øe he ≈øpeakes of an Almanack. I mu≈øt remember him, and he ≈øeemes onely to thinke of 1642. But 1641. mu≈øt not be forgotten, nor throwne a≈øide as out of date. There we finde fir≈øt a memorandum of the Northerne Army intended to bee brought up again≈øt the Parliament. By the good then, the chiefe Actors and proiectours of it, ≈øled beyond Sea in all ha≈øte, after once the Portugall Amba≈ø≈øadour had di≈øclaimed to Mr. Wadsworth that he knew Sir Iohn Suckling (or had any Commi≈ø≈øion to de≈øire Forces from the King for his Mrs. Service (who yet li≈øted and payed diver≈øe Officers and others, and gave ou ‚Ä¢ that he was to goe into Portugall with three or 400. Secondly, there we find a Memorandum of a great Lord that ≈øaid, when the Scots were once gone, they would teach the Hou≈øe of Commons better manners, who now did what the li≈øt, or to this effect. Thirdly, there we fi ‚Ä¢ nde a Memorandum, that about one and the ≈øame time, there was fir≈øt a ≈øtrange bu≈øine≈ø≈øe (GOD will in due time cleare it,) in Scotland,; and Secondly, the Popi≈øh Rebellion brake forth in Ireland: and thirdly, the Parliament was many wayes threatned in England, by Libells of ≈øeverall kinds, Quaeres, whether any Acts pa≈ø≈øed while two Armies were in the Kingdome were valid; Relations of Plots again≈øt prime Members; many intelligence of warning from forraine parts. Fourthly, there we find a Memorandum of the Iri≈øh Rebells, boa≈øtings of their Partie here, threatning to invade the Kingdome. 5. There we finde a Memorandum, that the King brought Winter with him out of Scotland (as he went thither in a kind of ≈øtorme, again≈øt the earne≈øt advi≈øe of both Hou≈øes, and after a ≈øevere ≈øpeech made by the Lord keeper in his name and pre≈øence) all clouds and never a Sun ≈øhine day all the yeare after. The priviledges of Parliament infringed in two or three things, are, the two Hou≈øes declared to him by a Petition of Decem 1.14. The Parliament guards di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, and a new one denied, though they de≈øired to tru≈øt the then Lord Chamberlaine of the Kings Hou≈øe: but another was offered to be put upon them, under the Command of the Lord Chamberlaine of the Queens Hou≈øe. All the≈øe Memorandums, the Almanak of 1641. affords, which all put together, make ≈øome what toward ‚Ä¢ he nece≈ø≈øitie of a preparation for Defence, at lea≈øt by petitioning for the Militia to be ≈øetled (Et≈øi non placent ≈øingula, juncta juvant.)

But now no ≈øooner doth our Almanack of 1642. appeare, but fir≈øt it pre≈øently pre≈øents us with the accu≈øation of the 6. Members; and ≈øecondly, ≈øtraight after with the Kings comming to the Hou≈øe of Commons, to demand the five Members of the Hou≈øe. The carriage of which bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, by the Kings Attendants, if any one will be ignorant of, let him be ≈øo; Res ip≈øa loquitur, the thing it ≈øelfe was ≈øo in the ≈øight of the Sunne, as was uncapable of a mi≈øtake; yet did an An≈øwer (to a Petition of the Maj ‚Ä¢ r, and Aldermen of the City, upon the occa≈øion of a few dayes after,) ≈øay that the King had no other Attendants, but onely Gentlemen armed with their Swords. Thirdly, about a week aft ‚Ä¢ r, the King withdrawes to Hampton-Court, and never returned to the Parliament ≈øince, (nor ever pa≈ø≈øed any Bill ≈øave that again≈øt Bi≈øhops Votes, and two or three about Ireland;) of which what the
Lord Digby ≈øaid to the Cavaliers, that came to the Hou≈øe of Commons, and how he behaved him≈øelfe at King≈øtone upon Thames, the Parliament hath ≈øufficiently declared, and in their Defence of their Remon≈øtrance of May 26. have ≈øhewed, that it is evident he did ≈øo carry him≈øelfe, though it have beene denyed. Fourthly his Letter (after he was fled) to the Queen, and another to Sir Lewes Dives coun≈øelling the King to retire to ≈øome ≈øtrong place, on which the Attempt on Hull, hath made an unhappy Comment, (and another ≈øince that ≈øurpri≈øed, written to the Queene, ≈øignifying what Coun≈øell he gave the King in a Letter, about that time which hath been ever ≈øince followed.) Fiftly, the Militia denyed for Cities and Corporations, (upon pretence of a Petition from the City of London, contrived by Binion, and ≈øome few others) which was of the greate≈øt con≈øequence for the Parliaments ≈øafety, and to keep out forraine Forces; and this when the Hou≈øes thought the King had granted it; (the meane while the Queen goes for Holland, in a ≈øtrange ≈øea≈øon of the yeare, and on a ≈ømall occa≈øion, (the Parliament having the yeare before, given Rea≈øons again≈øt her offering to goe beyond Sea, upon another pretence,) and how ≈øhe hath done ≈øince her going over, is too well knowne. Finally the Earle of Newca≈øtle in a di≈øgui≈øed habit and Name, and Captaine Legge, (two per≈øons that were named in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of bringing up the Northern Armes) came to Hull, and one of them, I remember now not which, but the Papers will tell,) ≈øhewed the Kings hand for to have had Hull, and the Magazine delivered up to him. And all this before the ≈øetling of the Militia by an Ordinance, or Sir Iohn Hothams taking in Forces to keep Hull ≈øafe. Let Con≈øcience now judge, whether all this gave not ju≈øt occa≈øion, for a preparation for Defence‚ñ™ and of a long time after this, nothing more was done, the Militia ≈øetled in very ‚Ä¢ ew Countries, till the Kings proceedings hath further warned them ‚Ä¢ o ≈øtand upon their guard, in other places be≈øides London.

It is true the King for a time had nothing but Proclamations and Declarations to oppo≈øe them. But after he was once gone Northward (and the Qu. beyond Sea‚ñ™) what did hee ever doe or ≈øay, but in oppo≈øition to them? and while his Declarations renounced all thoughts of Warre, notes were ≈øent over into Holland for Armes, and a beginning of an Army rai≈øed at Yorke, under the name of a Guard. When fir≈øt the Hou≈øes having petitioned the Removing the Magazine at Hull to London. (Upon a counter-Petition of a very few Gentlemen of York≈øhire, pretending the name of the whole County that it might be kept cleare ≈øtill) the King goes in≈øtantly to Hull, and demands entrance, intending as he declares to the Parliament after‚ñ™ that he meant ≈øo to doe) to take po≈ø≈øes≈øion of the Towne and Magazine, and di≈øpo≈øe of it: and being denyed, proclaimes Sir Iohn Hotham Traitor, without any proce≈ø≈øe of Law, or ≈øending fir≈øt to the Hou≈øe to know if they would owne it; and after demands ju≈øtice ≈øo peremptorily, as to deny before hand all other bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, but that of Ireland, (and how well that was done, we mu≈øt remember anon) and then was the Army rai≈øed under Colour of a Guard the York≈øhire men, not comming in readily enough to make it appeare a great Army.) And all this before ever it was declared by the Hou≈øes that the King ≈øeduced by wicked Councell, intended to make war again≈øt his Parliament, and ≈øo before ever they ≈øet out the Propo≈øitions for Money, Plate Hor≈øes, and therefore certainly before any one man was li≈øted. In all which the event hath ≈øhewed, that they were rather in wi≈ødome too ≈ølow, then in con≈øcience too quick in their Preparations for defence.
Remembring al≈øo, that as ≈øoone as the Ship (Providence) was come to them (a provdence indeed to di≈øcover what was before intended) the Siege was ≈øtraight ‚Ä¢ aid to Hu ‚Ä¢ , and the Declarations then ≈øpoke another Language then common men under≈øtood them to ≈øpeake before. For after all the Lords pre≈øent with the King had ≈øub≈øcrib ‚Ä¢ d (about Iune 16.) that they ≈øaw in the pretented Guard, &c. no intention of Warre again≈øt the Parliament: within few dayes, the King tels them, that if to ≈øeeke to recover Hull and the Magazine (then at London) and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the Militia) in all which the Parliament was engaged as much as could be) were to make Warre again≈øt the Parliament, he ever meant to doe the≈øe things, and had ever declared ≈øo; though I beleeve none that beleeved him did or could ≈øo under≈øtand: Let Con≈øcience now judge who began fir≈øt.

As touching the cau≈øe of the≈øe Armes, the Doctor would per≈øwade us, that it is for ≈øomthing which the King hath right to Deny. To evince which, he fir≈øt affirmes, that it cannot be for Religion or Priviledges and ancient Rights and Liberties, for the≈øe the King doth not deny.

REPL. But now ≈øufficient verball promi≈øes, with ≈øuch actions done (as were noted even now) are to ≈øecure Religion or the State, Con≈øcience mu≈øt judge, and it may a little the better, when we come to con≈øider them againe in the proper place for them (for here they outrunne their ≈øea≈øon like Abortives) in the next Section. REPL. 1. For the Militia, I referre to what hath beene ≈øaid, how ju≈øt rea≈øon the Parliament had to petition the ≈øecuring it, and after to ≈øettle it (as in ca≈øe of neces≈øity) by Ordinance. For di≈øpo≈øing Offices of State, it was never de≈øired, till the difference was very farre advanced, and Hull attempted; and Sir Iohn Hotham proclaimed Traitour, and the Army rai≈øed at Yorke, called a Guard. And in all their Declarations they never take it away; but contrarily in the defence of that May, 26. they grant, that though the King be bound by Oath and care of his people, not to deny any Bill for generall ≈øafety and good (for in ordinary matters they yeeld he may deny) Yet if he doe deny, it is no Law without him. The denyall then of the Militia only, in the ca≈øe of neces≈øity (with other things noted before) forced them to doe what they did toward Armes; and not any difference about a power of deniall in generall. 4. For the government and Revenue of the Church. I beleeve indeed it was a part of the cau≈øe of taking Armes; but not on the Parliaments part: the major part of whom in either Hou≈øe, never (till very lately) declared, nor ≈øhewed any purpo≈øe of taking either away quite, but only reforming (which the Doctor ≈øaith his Maje≈øty is alway ready to agree,) as may appeare even by the great agitations for ≈øo long in the Hou≈øe of Commons of
the Bill again≈øt Epi≈øcopacy root and branch; and at la≈øt it was wholly laid a≈øide; which ≈øhewes the major part never owned it as their delight. Kimbol ‚Ä¢ on, and the other five, and then came in that manner to the Hou≈øe of Commons to demand tho≈øe five.
