REPL. 1. He di≈øcovers a ≈øecret to us which we under≈øtood not before. All men ≈øtood amazed at the late Oath to this effect for the government; and among other Arguments again≈øt it not a few con≈øiderable men of the Mini≈øtry and Gentry before the Parliament lookt at it as an injury to the King, and oppo≈øite to our Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacie (and ≈øo the Parliament did in effect vote it) becau≈øe it urged men to ≈øweare never to con≈øent to alter the Government, which yet the King and State might pos≈øibly judge fit to be altered. But we never thought that the King was ≈øuppo≈øed bound by his Oath to it already; and much le≈ø≈øe that all Kings in ≈øucces≈øion would be bound (as now the Doctor teaches us) by their Oathes to maintaine it as it is by Law e≈øtabli≈øht. This it ≈øeems they pre≈øumed upon, and ≈øo thought to have made all ≈øure, by ≈øwearing all the Mini≈øtery and Univer≈øities, and Ma≈øters of Arts, and Schoolema≈øters, and Phy≈øitians‚ñ™ who would have had influence enough into the whole Kingdome within awhile. But God laught at this Project, turned it upon the Head of the Projectours and all the Party, as appeares this Day. And ≈øo I am per≈øwaded He will doe, all their Pre≈øent endeavours of Warre to recover them≈øelves. 2. But in good earne≈øt doth the Doctor (or any el≈øe) thinke the King bound by Oath to maintain Bi≈øhops ≈øtill in England (though he hath con≈øented to take them away in Scotland, to prevent War) even though he hazard the ruine of the Kingdome by a Civill Warre? and notwith≈øtanding any inconveniences repre≈øented to him by the complaints of his People, and the wi≈øedome of his Parliament, and his owne too? Or doth his Oath bind him to any more then to maintaine them ≈øo long as they are e≈øtabli≈øht by Law as he ≈øweares to maintaine all his other Subjects in their Rights; and yet an Act of Parliament may alter many things in mens Rights. Are not all Rights of Church and State (which are not properly jure divino) compromitted to the Parliament the three E≈øtates, King, Lords, Commons, every time they meet? And may they not alter and change this or that, ≈øo farre as it is humane and e≈øtabli≈øht but by the Lawes of the Land? The Kings Oath then binds not him and his Parliament from taking away Bi≈øhops, if they judge
them (not jure divino) and their continuance to be prejudiciall to the State and Church; (and ≈øo of Revenues the ≈øame may be ≈øaid.) 3. And if the Dr. will not admit this An≈øwere, but ≈øtill contend, the King did ≈øweare to maintaine them (at his Coronation) as they were then by Law e≈øtabli≈øhed. Is not the King beholding to him for charging him with Perjury (as in effect hee doth) ≈øince it is evident that by taking away the high Commis≈øion Court, and their power in their Courts of impo≈øing Oathes and Penalties, and after that their Votes in Parl. hee hath not maintain'd them as they were by Law e≈øtabli≈øht, when he tooke the Oath.

How the Doctor will an≈øwer this I know not: ≈øure I am, if any Mini≈øter having taken the Oath (never to con≈øent to alter the Government as it now ≈øtands e≈øtabli≈øht,) had offered to petition ≈øuch a taking away of their governing power; he ≈øhould quickly have beene accur≈øed as a perjured per≈øon, and accordingly ≈øo dealt with. It remaines then that the King onely ≈øwore to maintaine them according to Law; while they ≈øhould ≈øtand by Law, and not to bind him≈øelfe from any Law-making, though to take them away, in ca≈øe it ≈øhould appeare to be for the good of Church and State. And if this be not made good that their taking away will be ≈øo; let us all fight for them. But if it be, woe to tho≈øe men that hazard the King and two of his Kingdomes (England and Ireland) once more‚ñ™ (as before they would two yeares one after another, have hazarded England and Scotland) to maintaine Epi≈øcopall greatne≈ø≈øe and Authority. 4. What degree of Reformation (or any thing like to the Primitive Bi≈øhops) did they ever offer to be reduced unto? which might have contented Parliament and People both, if ever propounded in earne≈øt, to have asked no more. Or what cure for any effectuall Reformation have any of them (or their Party) ever ≈øhewed ≈øince the Parliament met, to have rendred it any way hopefull that they would bee good in≈øtruments hereafter? 5. If therfore after all warnings, they will needs put the King ≈øtill on (as it appeares even by the Doctors words) to fight for their maintenance: Let them remember Mr. Brightmans Propheticall Interpretation of the ≈øpewing out of the Laodicean Angell. And though a vomiting ≈øomtimes makes a mans heart ≈øick, and ready to dye; yet where he hath ≈øtrength of Nature it comes up at la≈øt, and proves happy cure. Which in this ca≈øe (if it be Chri≈øts act‚ñ™ as it much ≈øeemes to be) will not faile to bee fulfilled to our comfort at la≈øt, how weake ≈øoever it bring us fir≈øt. I conclude this then, that as Phy≈øick is upon the defen≈øive‚ñ™ ≈øo much more the endeavour to ca≈øt up the humour which unprovoked or but a little ≈øtirred, endangers the Bodies health by Inflamations & the like. So the late voting down the B ‚Ä¢ s‚ñ™ was meerly defen≈øive; and the War, ≈øo much as it is to maintaine them, them≈øelves are and ever were upon the offen≈øive, and offenders, in and the Parliament not at all.

Now for the managing of the re≈øi≈øtance, the Doctor offers to examine whether it hath beene ≈øo void of Ho≈øtility as that defen≈øive way, they pretend to, ≈øhould bee. Let us examine it with him. Here he contends 1. that the Defendant ≈øhould be of an≈øwerable demeanour to David defending him≈øelfe again≈øt Saul. REP. But he may be plea≈øed to con≈øider, that as all that handle the difference betweene an offen≈øive War and a defen≈øive, do rationally maintain, that he that is outragiou≈øly injuried (as David in his Emba≈ø≈øadors, 2 Sam.
‚Ä¢ 0.) Or dangerou≈øly threatned, is but on the defen≈øive; though he be actually ‚Ä¢ n Armes fir≈øt, through diligence and ≈øome advantages perhaps: ≈øo a man‚ñ™
keeps him≈øelfe within the bounds of a defence, though he actually offend him that does, or that would a≈ø≈øault him, and even though he begin fir≈øt. So David did in the former ca≈øe, invading the Ammonites Country, and yet he was properly defen≈øive. So a man on the high way, if a Robber ≈øhould a≈ø≈øault him; if he could prevent his blow and ≈øtrike fir≈øt, it were but in his owne defence: but much more to ≈øtrike againe and kill (if he cannot otherwi≈øe defend him≈øelfe) which yet is the highe≈øt degree of offence betweene party and party. Ob. But David ≈øtill withdrew and having taken the Kings ≈øpeare and cru≈øe, he re≈øtored them without demand. Rep. True, but I have formerly given the rea≈øon why he ever withdrew, Pag. I need not repeat it. And as for the cru≈øe and ≈øpeare, he tooke them not away for feare of being hurt by them (as now Ammunitions and other provi≈øions) but as the Dr. well ≈øayes, to ≈øhew Abners neglect and his own integrity; and therfore when they had done him that ≈øervice, he re≈øtored them without demand. But the Parl. cannot fly from place to place like David; they mu≈øt keep at We≈øtmin≈øter, or di≈ø≈øolve them≈øelves; and they have offered to re≈øtore that which they took to prevent their own and the Kingdomes being mi≈øchefed by it; ≈øo that ≈øecurity might have been obtained for time to come; witne≈ø≈øe the Petition ≈øent by the E. of Holland and others to Beverley, while Hull was be≈øieged. In a word there hath been nothing done in this kind, of all that the Dr. reckons up, which meer neces≈øity hath not forced; and mo≈øt of tho≈øe things mu≈øt have beene done by David, if he had kept Keilah again≈øt Saul as he de≈øired and meant to have done. 2, And whereas the Dr. further urges [that the Kings loyall and peaceable Subjects are a≈ø≈øaulted, de≈øpoiled of their Armes, goods, e≈øtates, their per≈øons impri≈øoned, becau≈øe they would according to their allegiance as≈øi≈øt him in this extremity; or would not contrary to their con≈øcience, joyne with them again≈øt him] Rep. This concerns two ≈øorts of per≈øons; and for both‚ñ™ though ≈øomwhat differently, the ≈øatisfaction to this allegation depends upon the ju≈øtice of the defence it ≈øelfe. For 1. if the Parl. do ju≈øtly take up Arms, then without all doubt (however the Dr. talks of an implicit faith) they may ≈øeize upon the arms goods e≈øtates‚ñ™ per≈øons of tho≈øe that actually under what pretence ≈øoever) as≈øi≈øt again≈øt them. Though if their defence be not ju≈øt, then all this is confe≈ø≈øedly a multiplication of inju≈øtice: but if they may fight with the Army that oppo≈øes them, they may di≈øarm, &c. tho≈øe that ≈øtrengthen the army with monys &c. 2. as for tho≈øe that only wold not, contrary to their con≈øcience joyn with them again≈øt him, I have 2. things to ≈øay. 1. If any of the≈øe have in former times any way promoted illegall commands and practi≈øes it is much to be doubted they can bring but ≈ølender proof of their forbearing to joyn with the Parl. out of con≈øcience. There is nothing more ea≈øie then to pretend con≈øcience in all controverted points. But hee de≈øerves not to be beleeved in his pretence, that hath been but even now (and much more if he be ≈øtill) a violatour of rules of con≈øcience in other re≈øpects. It is wel known how tender they have been of other mens con≈øciences in needle≈øs Ceremonies, in illegall Innovations, in prophane violations of the Lords Sabbath and the 4th. Com. who now cry con≈øcience to ≈øave their mony, or to weaken the Parl. 2. If any be really con≈øcientious in the point; ye ‚Ä¢ upon the neces≈øity of a ju≈øt def ‚Ä¢ nce the Parl. may as well ≈øecure their per≈øons, and ≈øpecially their Armes‚ñ™ and levy ≈øome monies upon them as in a common danger of a forrain enemy trenches may be digged on a mans Land or Forts built ev ‚Ä¢ n again≈øt his will‚ñ™ and in a fire breaking violently out the next hou≈øe may be p ‚Ä¢ l'd downe to ≈øave a towne or many more hou≈øes. Though it is al≈øo true, that ≈øuch
ought to have recompence afterward when al the danger is over, and ≈øo I doubt not, but all truely con≈øciencious ≈øhall have in due time. When it ≈øhall appeare they only forbeare out of con≈øcience, and did no acts of malignancy withall; nor ≈øpoke malignantly again≈øt the Parliament and their ju≈øt proceedings.

The Mode≈øty of ≈øome (of many) that have ≈øuffered a great deale wor≈øe within the≈øe few yeares, then the Parliament makes their mo≈øt Malignant Pri≈øoner, ≈øuffer may ≈øufficiently ≈øhew, what a Con≈øcientious refu≈øall ≈øignifies, if it be no more but ≈øo. And if the Parliam. have nothing more to An≈øwer for then rigour again≈øt ≈øuch, the Dr. will hardly prove, they have tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed the bounds of a lawfull defence. His reproaches therfore in the clo≈øe of this Sect. I let pa≈ø≈øe and come at la≈øt to his 7. & la≈øt Sect. wherunto‚ñ™ if as good a reply can be made as to the former, I ≈øhall not much doubt the Sentence of Con≈øcience (of any one who is unengaged or unpartial) in the whole Que≈øtion between us.

div.head: SECT. 7.
div.p: WE are now come to the Tendre≈øt Peece of all the Re≈øt; and how confidently ≈øo ever the Dr. charges the Parliament and all that cleave to them with Rendring the King odious, &c. and ≈øaith it concernes them ≈øo to doe; yet it ≈øhall appeare by what I have to reply to him in this Section, how little delight I have to make the King Odious, and that the Parliament al≈øo hath and doth as much as lay in them to put off all Imputations from the King and charge them (as the Law doth) upon his Councellors, Judges, Followers and Favourites. Here 1. let me remember him; that whereas in other Kingdomes, ≈øome Favourites, when they have ≈øeen their Prince endangered have rather taken his actions upon them≈øelves, then ca≈øt theirs on him, and been content to Sacrifice them≈øelves rather for his ≈øafety, then expo≈øe him to ≈øhield them≈øelves. It hath been the continuall practi≈øe of the plotters again≈øt our Religion, and Liberties to Entitle the King to all their Illegallities and Oppre≈øsions; There can ≈øcarce that Grievance be named (if we except the Ship-money which was devolved upon the Judges, and yet it is well knowne how they were tampered with in the Kings Name) which they have not Fraudulently gotten the King to own as his Act; and this is their con≈øtant practi≈øe to this day, who then hath laboured to make the King Odious? or whom did it concerne but they? that ≈øo far as the people would finde fault with any thing‚ñ™ they ≈øhould be forced in a ≈øort to finde fault with the King; and this al≈øo helped to Charme all Tongues‚ñ™ and tie down all hands till they provoked the Scots beyond all degrees of ≈øufferance, to come in with an Army and demand ≈øecurity in and by an Engli≈øh Parl. a≈øwell as one in Scotland.
2. Next whereas the Dr. upbraids the Parliament and People, [That it ≈øeemes they are men that would be loath to ≈øuffer for their Religion, they are ≈øo ready to fly to Armes to ≈øecure them≈øelves]

Repl. 1. It ill becomes a pretender to, and Di≈øputer for Con≈øcience to ≈øpeake this Language that hath lived to ≈øee how many ≈øufferings (though not re≈øi≈øting to blood‚ñ™ ≈øtriving again≈øt ≈øinne) many even of the Parliament, but ≈øpecially of the Mini≈øtery and people have yeelded to within 16. or 18. yeares, and never thought of flying to Armes, but rather of flying out of their Native Country, as thou≈øands have done: Unle≈ø≈øe the Dr. will undertake to ju≈øtifie, all that was Impo≈øed upon mens Con≈øciences all this while; And if he will do ≈øo he ≈øhall ≈øave many Con≈øciences a labour to judge with what a Con≈øcience hee Writes. 2. Doth he thinke, that they could be ≈øo ≈øimple as not to
fore≈øee that their very flying to Armes was and would be a great ≈øuffering, and might prove (if God ≈øhould defeat them) the meanes of extreame ≈øuffering. A people ≈øo taught, ≈øo enured to Pa≈øsive obedience, and no way enured to Warre, could not be ≈øuppo≈øed willing or forward to engage them≈øelves, their pur≈øes, or much le≈ø≈øe their Per≈øons, again≈øt the Name of their King: and each day ≈øince the fir≈øt Nece≈øsity hath continually ≈øounded this out, ≈øo that they had no rea≈øon to be forward to fly to Armes. 3. By what I ≈øaid on the former Section, and added with the Petition by the E. of Holland (even now mentioned) It appeares they did not fly to Armes but fly from it, as far as they could and dur≈øt. 3. Wheras the Dr. often in this Section, in the beginning, middle and end in≈øi≈øts mainly, upon the breach of Charity, in ≈øu≈øpecting the King upon Remote feare, and meere Jealou≈øies, cau≈øele≈ø≈øe Jealou≈øies &c.

Repl. This may ≈øufficiently be ≈øatisfied both in the behalfe of the Parliament, and then of the People that adhere to them joyntly and ≈øingly. For the Parliament and people both joyntly; This may ju≈øtly be ≈øaid, 1. The Dr. mi≈øtakes, it is not ≈øimply a Jealou≈øie of the King, but rather of the Kings Councellors and Followers, who find ≈øo much favour with him (as they and others did before the Parliament again≈øt the Scots and us both, and Ireland too, witne≈ø≈øe all their heavy complaints again≈øt the Great Favourite Strafford) that they are able to put him from time to time, upon the≈øe Actions which his goodne≈ø≈øe of it ≈øelfe, rightly informed and councelled, would abhorre; and hath ≈øo often declared again≈øt, and yet Actions againe have di≈øcredited tho≈øe declarations, as the Memory of tho≈øe that have been awake cannot forget, both Referring to Religion and Liberties and the Parliament Remon≈øtrances do amply ≈øet out, be≈øids other Books. If therfore Security be once obtained again≈øt ≈øuch per≈øons; I am per≈øwaded the King will be no more ≈øu≈øpected; and in the meane time, it mu≈øt be a ≈øtrange Charity that can chu≈øe but ≈øu≈øpect them. 2. Where the danger is of much importance, both for Greatne≈ø≈øe of Mi≈øchiefe and Inevitablene≈ø≈øe according to Man, if not timely prevented; Charity to our≈øelves (and others) will not onely allow, but commend, and even command to ≈øu≈øpect and accordingly prevent, ≈øuch dangers by ≈øu≈øpecting Per≈øons and Actions which in le≈ø≈øer matters they would and might and ≈øhould venture to tru≈øt. Fire neere ≈øtraw or Gunpowder, is to be ≈øu≈øpected more then neere hard wood. Hedge-breakers and breakers of Hou≈øes are not equally to be ≈øu≈øpected. Religion‚ñ™ Laws and Liberties are precious things and may be ≈øooner lo≈øt then recovered. And his Charity hath drunk of the water of Lethe, that forgets the≈øe were lately attempted and endangered. (The Kings own Declarations acknowledge Laws and Liberties have been broken.) And how ≈øince the E. of Straffo ‚Ä¢ ds death, all the old Projectors are become Converts, is too hard a mor≈øell for Charity to ≈øwallow, when it mu≈øt hazard ≈øuch deare things to many of the ≈øame Per≈øons againe. Specially ≈øeeing ≈øtill, what they have done ≈øince the fir≈øt ≈øitting of the Parliam. toward their old Projects, as hath been partly noted already and ≈øomewhat more mu≈øt be ≈øaid by and by.

Next for the Parliament alone. They are the great Councell of the Kingdome the publique Watch-men, the Highe≈øt Court of Judicature, it concerns them therfore to exerci≈øe their Charity, for the ≈øafety of tho≈øe that have tru≈øted them. Charity towards Attempters again≈øt a City, is none of the Vertues of a Watchman, nor toward Attempters of dangerous Trea≈øons again≈øt a King and Kingdome, the Vertue of a Judge. Were they onely to loo≈øe their
own Liberties or Lives, their Charity might venture much further, then now it may, when they mu≈øt An≈øwer for Religion, Laws, and Liberties (and ≈øo Lives and Con≈øciences) of a whole Kingdome, of 2 Kingdomes, England and Ireland, as formerly of England and Scotland, if not rather then and ≈øtill, of all 3. in a degree. Who would not Cur≈øe their Charity, dete≈øt their Folly, if by their Credulity, all this ≈øhould be betrayed and ruined. If Rhetorick needed in this cau≈øe, no Subject could de≈øerve it better, then to cry down ≈øuch a pernitious Charity, as this would prove, if they ≈øhould be deceived with credulity.

And then for the People alone, have they not a charity to exerci≈øe toward the Parliament, as well as toward the Kings Followers; whom have they tru≈øted to be publike Watchmen, the one or the other? Whom hath the law tru≈øted to be the great Councell and chief Judges, the one or the other? Who hath pleaded for their Liberties the one or the other? 12. Sub≈øidies were demanded (with intent thereby to engage us in a bloody War again≈øt Scotland) in the Parliament of Aprill, 1640. Onely for taking away of Ship-money. But this Parliament hath proved it ≈øo illegall and other things more, that it was taken away without any co≈øt at all, by way of Exchange, and many other happy Lawes hath the
‚Ä¢ arliament pa≈ø≈øed, and obtained for us. But what one thing did the Kings former Coun≈øellors move him to offer to his people, by way of prevention, for State or Religion, in a whole yeer together? To whom then mu≈øt the People exerci≈øe their charity? Mu≈øt they condemn their watchmen, as ≈øcaring them needle≈ø≈øely with Old Enemies, di≈øcredit the law that ≈øaith. [No di≈øhonourable thing ought to be thought of ≈øuch a great Councell, ≈øuch a high Judicature.] And that when they, more then ever any Parliament before give account to all men, of all their Actions and the grounds of them? Well, ≈øhall that People de≈øerve a ruine, that believe Old Wolves, rather then their faithfull Dogs, then their Councell of Shepheards: That ≈øhall thinke them≈øelves bound to be charitable, to tho≈øe that have attempted their ruine, and uncharitable to tho≈øe that under God have hitherto ≈øaved them. In a word, let tho≈øe that love Religion, and Laws, and Liberties compare the be≈øt actions on the one ≈øide, with the be≈øt on the other, and the wor≈øt on the one ≈øide, with the wor≈øt on the other: and then let charity judge (if it dare, or can) the Parliament Fooles or Traytors, to GOD and the KING, and the STATE; and the Kings followers, the only wi≈øe men, that have di≈øcovered their cunning Treachery, and the only faithfull men to Religion, his Maje≈øty and Kingdome. Take in then‚ñ™ the Declarations and Prote≈øtations; on the one ≈øide‚ñ™ and on the other, and remember is is not a ≈øingle charity, whether I ≈øhall ≈øu≈øpect the King; but fir≈øt mixt‚ñ™ whether I ≈øhall or may ≈øu≈øpect the Kings followers who can doe any thing with him ≈øo farre, as that they may doe contrary to what he ≈øaith and then a di≈øtingui≈øhing charity‚ñ™ whether I ≈øhall ≈øu≈øpect them, who were once (mo≈øt of them apparently) Delinquents, again≈øt Religion and the Laws, Or the Publike Watchmen, and the great Councell an Judicature of the Kingdom: who have done ≈øo much and with ≈øuch diligence to ≈øave and re≈øtore both and then let Con≈øcience exerci≈øe charity as it will an≈øwer to GOD, to it ≈øelfe to all it's Fellow Engli≈øh men and Chri≈øtians, and even to the whole World. Thus in generall, now we mu≈øt examine ≈øome particulars.

The Dr. names 4, grounds of feares and jealou≈øie, with which the people have been po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. All which he fir≈øt rejects with a gentle comparing of the Parliamont (who hath ≈øet them forth) to the Devill the Arch-accu≈øer. This is
his charity. In ≈øtead of rataliating, I will onely ≈øay the Lord forgive thee‚ñ™

His fir≈øt ground is [Reports of Forraign Power to be brought in. This, he ≈øaith, was given out before the ≈øetting up of the MILITIA, to keepe the People amu≈øed, the ea≈øier to draw them into ≈øuch a po≈øture of defence as was pretended; and they are all di≈øcovered by time to have been vaine.]

REPL. 1. why will he perpetually forget that the King him≈øelf granted the Militia nece≈ø≈øary to be ≈øetled. 2 It was not meerely Forraigne Forces to bee brought in; but Papi≈øts and Delinquents ri≈øing at home, that was in≈øinuated a cau≈øe of the de≈øire to have the Kingdom put in a po≈øture of defence. 3. Who knows not of the billeting of many thou≈øands of Iri≈øh upon us even during the fitting of a former Parliament? The Project of Germane Hor≈øe in the Dukes time is it quite forgotten? The Earle of Staffords Councell, not only to bring in his Iri≈øh Army con≈øi≈øting mo≈øt of Papi≈øts, wherewith to reduce this Kingdome, was it not proved by the Oath of a Privy Coun≈øellor pre≈øent, and confirmed by his own Notes taken at the time, and did not the re≈øt of the advi≈øe then given by that Politician, (that the King being now de≈øerted by his Parliament, might doe any act of power (Quaere the words in his charge) amount to Coun≈øelling the bringing in of any forces from any place? And why mu≈øt all intelligences after the≈øe prevented, bee counted vaine 4. For is all ≈øu≈øpition vaine, becau≈øe the thing ≈øu≈øpected comes not to pa≈ø≈øe, when mean are u≈øed to prevent it? Is all preventing Phy≈øicke Vaine? Is all feare of Pyrates in a Sea voyage vaine, if none a≈ø≈øault a well man'd and provided Ship? Was not ≈øuch a Navy being ≈øecured in ≈øafe hands, as would under God have made great Forraign Forces repent their comming again≈øt the Kingdomee; competent rea≈øon why tho≈øe that did mean to come (if they might have had no re≈øi≈øtance on the Sea) now thought it too hot a ≈øervice? 5. But be≈øides the Navy, they had no Landing place, Hull being contrary to the Court-expectation (and attempt as was Noted before) ≈øecured by the Parliament, and ≈øo might well be the more di≈øcouraged. 6. Which is the more con≈øiderable, because no ≈øooner had they got a Port-Town, namely Newca≈øtle; but though no Forraign Forces came, who could not be ≈øo ≈øoon ready; yet Forraign Ammunition came, not a little; and Forces of our Country-men, who ≈øerved in Forraign Countries, and money too, from Forraigne Princes or People.
